content.content: Overview The Asset Allocation for MIP65 was set 20/6/2022. Much has changed since then in the capital markets (!) and consequently we’d like to propose a change to this asset allocation. Here’s the previous Asset Allocation Poll for reference.  Proposal We would like to propose reallocating the DAI 250M, initially allocated towards a mixed, medium-term focused, corporate and government bond investment mandate with Baillie Gifford, to ISIN IE00BGSF1X88 : 0-1y US Treasury ishares/Blackrock ETF product resulting in the following ultimate allocation of the DAI 500M under MIP65:     Amount ETF W. Avg. YTM W. Avg. Maturity 3y SD     350M 0-1y US TreasuryIE00BGSF1X88 3.5% 0.37 0.38%   150M 1-3y US TreasuryIE00BYXPSP02 4.3% 1.86 1.77%     Considerations This reallocation proposal is a reaction to two principal concerns:  Corporate Bond performance under a recession This could be the best time in history to buy Corporate Bonds - or it could be the worst. Recession is more and more a definite and we - nor anybody else - has a crystal ball to predict how the corporate bond market would react under a prolonged period of recession. We feel uncomfortable making a bet on this market. We might have been comfortable moving towards highest quality Corporate Bonds (AAA), but our concern about general market volatility (below) leads us to unfortunately propose leaving this asset class for the time being.  General market volatility Just about all asset markets have increased dramatically in market-value volatility - for many reasons. The recent UK Gilt shock is a good example of the current materially increased randomness put into the capital markets dynamic system. Whilst we might be comfortable about the long-term return and value of highly rated (AAA) corporate Bonds and long-term Government Bonds, we are concerned about short-term shocks in market-values that could lead to sentiment-driven negative extreme shock actions on Maker and DAI. Thus we, for the time being, propose fundamentally only deploying capital towards short-term government bonds in a highly liquid ETF product.  1139×493 93.4 KB  ICE BoFAML MOVE Index (essentially measures volatility in bond markets) The resulting portfolio above is more a “Collect basic yield and wait-and-see where the world goes” portfolio than a “bet” on a particular path for the world economy. We would expect to propose a further reallocation as the world economy finds a more stable trajectory.  Our patient friends at Baillie Gifford This reallocation is, of course, a disappointment as we were keen to start work with Baillie Gifford and engage them further with the Maker Community. Luckily Baillie Gifford is 114 years old and takes a long-term view on things such as partnerships. This reallocation closes no doors with Baillie Gifford and we hope to include them in any future reallocation discussions when the world economy shows some basic stability in direction (pending, of course, how regulations and compliance requirements develop - as we all know - this area remains in substantive flux in most countries on crypto). We will remain positively engaged with Baillie Gifford to explore opportunities and thank them for their engagement with Maker so far and hope we find ways to collaborate soon.  Asset Reallocation Vote on MIP65 / DAI 250M     Reallocate to ISIN IE00BGSF1X88 : 0-1y US Treasury ishares/Blackrock ETF Do not reallocate Abstain     0 voters      Next Step This signal will run until Sunday, 2022-10-23T00:00:00Z. If more than 50% of the non-abstaining votes are in favour it will move to an on-chain poll on Monday, Oct 24th.
content.GPT-summary: The post explains a proposal to reallocate assets for MIP65 due to concerns about corporate bond performance and general market volatility. The proposal suggests reallocating DAI 250M to a short-term government bond ETF product. The post also mentions the disappointment of not being able to work with Baillie Gifford due to the reallocation but expresses hope for future collaboration. The post includes a vote on the proposed asset reallocation. Some third parties ask questions and provide constructive criticism.

content.content: The following is GovAlpha’s summary of this Signal Request.  This is a valid Signal Request. This signal request gauges community sentiment towards taking 250M Dai initially allocated towards a mixed, medium-term focused, corporate and government bond investment and reallocates it to short-term US treasury bonds. The motivation for the reallocation is current market volatility and uncertainty over the performance of corporate bonds during a recession. This Signal Request will run until Sunday, October 23. If the outcome is a majority of non-abstain votes in favour of proceeding, an on-chain poll will follow on Monday, October 24. This SR has been assigned High-Impact based on the methodology listed here.  Disclaimer: These summaries are intended to be a guide and not a source of truth. You remain responsible for any actions you take on the grounds of this information. Please note the date when the summary was last updated to judge accuracy. Updated 2022-10-13

content.content: We’ve discussed the matter with Allan over the weekend. We came independently in the view over the last months that credit/duration risks have little to offer in the current situation. We will soon get (?) 4% “risk-free” so what’s the point on getting to 5.5% with risk? Especially as we are still in the learning phase. It is not so much additional basis points that should be the focus for now, but how to have a bigger base invested. Should such a Signal Request succeed, it will be used to indicate a non-binding sentiment of the MakerDAO community towards prospectives “asset managers”/liquidity strategies. IB01 is not without duration risk, but with an average duration of 0.4 years, any mark-to-market loss would quickly be covered by the 3.43% yield to maturity  (a 100bps unexpected rate hike would be amortized in a month). It is the shorter duration treasury bonds we have to chose from. The fact that we invest by 50M bulk is also good to mitigate this risk. I am also disappointed that we are not investing right now with Baillie Gifford. Working with a separately managed account (SMA) and a top tier asset manager will provide more flexibility and probably a better optimization. It is quite complementary to a ETF investments. Nevertheless, KYC is still in process and so I view it is only as a delay. Proposing a thread for community to have a more broader discussion on the short-term bonds strategy. Feel free to discuss the broader topic there and the specifics of MIP65 here.

content.content: ACREinvest:  Can you say more about the KYC process? Who is being KYC’d and by whom?   It’s handled by Monetalis. James Asset PTC Limited is KYCed, by JPMorgan (custodian) and Baillie Gifford (asset managers). KYC from Coinbase and Bank Sygnum is already done.     ACREinvest:  Who is able to provide the community with an objective risk assessment of this ETF product?   Some short risk assessment was provided here. On the underlying financials instrument it is strictly safer than the BG allocation. You can also read the analysis for 1-3 years treasury bonds. IB01 is significantly less risky. The ETF provides a regulatory document describing risks. Happy to answer any specific question.     ACREinvest:  Can someone share a link to information in the forum or other summary that shows a simple picture of all the counterparty relationships and fees involved in this ETF proposal   Monetalis MIP65 Documentation HQ?  |1029.4562211981568x579.58839273173911280×720 71.6 KB  For the fees, Monetalis gets 15bps, Sygnum some custody fees (and transaction fees, not sure those are public, but it’s market rates) and Blackrock the 7bps of the ETF.

content.content: I believe with the possibility of a European Energy crisis and the current UK policy response (which arguably, could make inflation worse) I believe it is wise to move away from the proposed original strategy of Corporate Bonds and shift to a highly liquid ETF of short-term Government Bills. Move to support. On the subject of short-term bills and the risk that interest rates will continue to rise, assuming nominal rates go to 4.25-4.75% and stay flat in 2023 (and inflation stays persistent at 4%++) — how do you believe that will effect the duration and convexity of the 1-3y US Treasury IE00BYXPSP02 ETF, assuming EU bonds and Gilts continue to have a high convexity rate, and the fact that All bond markets are correlated (assuming you agree). More importantly, @SebVentures @Allan_Pedersen  have any of you done any Risk Analysis on the convexity of the 1-3y T-Bills assuming rates trend higher in the next 6-12 months? Is it possible this ETF will underperform assuming the convexity of 1-3y T-Bills sees interest rates decline (doubt it, but wondering what is the risk of underperforming).

content.content: A few thoughts for you. Let me start by showing you two charts from Pensford - maybe you have seen them before.   My bet would be that Fed will probably hike in November (75bps), December(50bps) and once next year(25bps) - and then it will take 1 year or so to start reducing rates - to ensure transmission into the economy - hike has been very fast. That is somewhat a good case I guess. I think a good number of countries will have to truly throw in the towel if increasing rates are going to continue over 2023 at the current blazing pace. Anyhow - stable market are not expected for quite some months to come in my basic view. A duration of 0.37 - with this backdrop - may not produce us to largest returns, but ensures lowest market value variability - which is really what I am most worried about. The markets are hypersensitive and seem to be reacting almost violently to small upsets - and I am concerned that this hypersensitivity can be even amplified in “crypto-land” - a paper market-value loss on a small portfolio can lead to very odd behaviours when everybody is on the edge. So I like a very short duration portfolio that can somewhat follow the movements that seem reasonably sensible to expect being in store and that doesn’t act out too much in even extreme cases. If all goes well rate stability comes in February/March (I hope!) and we can start thinking a bit more long-term on assets that have a market-value consequence we need to consider - and reallocate to something more interesting. Remember this is an allocation made to sit in the low-risk/high liquid/large scale bottom of the balance sheet pyramid. Not the small, high-yielding, private asset, long-term top-end of the pyramid. So primary focus probably is stability with some return, which today, my bet is, only really comes in the form of very short US Treasuries. …and - I guess - if I am wrong - ie. you could have made more return on longer durations safely - well then that is a better kind of wrong, than if someone is wrong about being in longer duration bonds and gets a market-value smack-down that ignites all kinds of drama.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Thanks for this @Allan_Pedersen and @SebVentures . While I am sure that all/most our delegates can handle the complexity of this signal request, I think in the future it would be useful, at least for  `methodological’ reasons, to ask a third (external) opinion to inform better the community and delegates. What I mean is something similar to what, e.g. PECU, asks regularly for critical new smart-contracts: an external audit with a clear professional report and opinion, that anybody can read. This said I have a very naive question:     SebVentures:  We will soon get (?) 4% “risk-free” so what’s the point on getting to 5.5% with risk? Especially as we are still in the learning phase. It is not so much additional basis points that should be the focus for now, but how to have a bigger base invested.   QUESTION: why not going 100% with 0-1y US Treasury (IE00BGSF1X88)?

content.content: We could try to find a third party, but this is uncharted territory. We mandated a review of the ALM framework a few months ago. This validated the investment in t-bonds. For the details it’s more like parameters of Liq2.0 given by risk or what the MOMC is proposing (which I hope the MOMC will take the duty to ease the burden at some point). Going all in on 0-1y is an option probably. It’s just that it start to be very small nuances that don’t matter much. An allocation to 1-3yr will be needed at some point so we might as well keep it to avoid too much transaction fees. Using the 0-1yr is really a liquidity buffer (imperfect but the best we have in this structure). The goal of this reallocation is more to remove the credit risk which there will be no longer in MIP65.

content.content: Something to notice is that mkr is starting to bleed stablecoin backed DAI.  We’re down 100 mil in the last week and that might start to accelerate.  You might be hitting a point where the spread is large enough that people are beginning to sell DAI to get access to treasuries or other rates that are indirectly influenced by fed rates.  How close are we to getting this setup?  You’ve still got plenty of excess DAI demand but clock may be ticking…

content.content: Traster_Tray:  You might be hitting a point where the spread is large enough that people are beginning to sell DAI to get access to treasuries or other rates that are indirectly influenced by fed rates.   I believe the main instrument to counter-balance this will be the DSR (``DAI Saving Rate’'). Basically we will give DAI holders a cut of the pie, so that everybody is happy.

content.content: I think this is more effective for keeping holders happy and less effective for drawing people back to DAI since I don’t imagine we intend to give a DSR anywhere close to the treasury rates. Maybe you could optimize it so that rates go up and down based on certain DAI demand thresholds.  But nothing happens until we have access to those treasury rates so I’m just curious how close we are.

content.content: The DAI Savings Rate plus risk-free floating rate loans like cash value lines of credit could be the solution to many problems.
Thats the way but we dont have the revenue (current state revenue streams) to activate DSR right now, that is why asset deployment should be Maker’s top action item
